name: huber
text: Ok, I understand that this strip has no meaning if read on its own - but just quietly... how awesome is Robert Johnson

name: deimosrising
text: Extremely is how. I have now turned my musickal device to his songs, and I am listening to them.

name: huber
text: dude, try slowing down your robert johnson records hey - by as much as 20%. It sounds kinda awesome. (Chuck Berry also sounds pretty ace slowed down)

name: deimosrising
text: I'm kind of liking it. Gives it a more familiar, delta kind of sound.

name: mira
text: Congrats on making it all the way through the archives!

name: deimosrising
text: Haha. My avatar still says 1219 but I'm completely certain I've been through ever strip (some others, like yours, say 1220). I don't know if one didn't register or it's a bug or what.

name: mira
text:
I'm thinking it's a bug.

At one point there were bug-pages you could view, and they would raise your count. Those seem to have been dealt with, though. I'm suspecting this one has something to do with viewing a comic on the main page and then viewing it in the archives.

name: riazm
text: There should be a secret club for those who have viewed the entire archive. Sort of a Platinum Reserve thing. We could have a drink!

name: tekende
text: And sit around with a delighted expression on our faces.

name: greenkoolayd
text: do we get a key to the executive washroom?

name: fattypneumonia
text:
V.P's don't piddle with the piffle!

HA HAAA! Vee...PEE!!!

name: radarjammer
text: I would piss in your mouth. I would call it "Robert Johnson's magic fountain".

name: boredom_man
text: We should have all the drinks!

name: choosebro
text: I'm currently on my second tour of duty. I'm enjoying it as much as I did the first time around.

name: charchar
text: I used to set my 33s to 45.  I tried  it at 78 one time, and it made Robert (Smith, in this case) sound like a chipmunk.  It's a secondhand vinyl, and I'm pretty sure I'm the first person to do that without being high.

name: tellumo
text: Naah, my brothers and I had a Fisher-Price turntable when we were kids and we'd sometimes play records at the wrong speed. Playing a Chipmunks 33 at 45 is what made me decide that those guys were no-good losers; playing a Sesame Street 33 at 45, I believe, contributed to my current liking of Sonic Youth.

name: jthm_guitarist
text: Another great person to slow down is Geddy Lee.

name: nabeel84
text: How do you people slow it down? What software?

name: i_love_kate
text: Nabeel84 has been lamed for not knowing something about technology.

name: wite_rabit
text: God, I hope you're kidding.

name: nabeel84
text: I am not.

name: wite_rabit
text: Record players were switchable between speeds. On records to be played at 45 if you instead played it slower at 33 it would, naturally, sound slower.

name: nabeel84
text: I knew that, I was hoping someone had some music software where they could do that.

name: wite_rabit
text: Sound Recorder - I meant to lame that post..

name: mattylite
text: Awesome, I thought I was the only one who liked some stuff slower (Springsteen Born in the USA, particularly "I'm Goin' Down") or faster.  I also found something amazing doing this: if you slow down the Pointer Sisters, it sounds just like Billy Ocean.  If you speed up Billy Ocean, though, it doesn't sound like the Pointer Sisters.  What the hell?

name: relaxing
text: what the hell

name: autrepoupee
text: my goshes 'n' gadzooks, you are so right about this!  it is indeed a strange universe.

name: invidious
text: What we need more of... is science! (Meaning: the science Mattylite practices.)

name: mashisoyo
text: A good friend of mine will often bust out a Gracie Fields 45 at 33 speed to his blazed guests. It's quite an experience to hear "The Biggest Aspidistra in the World" sung by what sounds like Brad Neely's Babycakes.

name: sweetlips
text: One time I made up an imaginary super-hero league the members of which were Rasputin, Edward Teach, and Robert Johnson.

name: poodlelucy
text: 1. great music; 2. last name is johnson. he is indeed awesome.

name: mr_pete
text: This is a fine strip because it makes me wonder if I were pulling up a Best Western in the Aboveworld and Robert Johnson were playing in a bar would I notice? Such contemplation is fine for a man, like the whisper of memento mori.

name: spinynorman
text: I think this and Wristcutters are afterlives I can deal with.

name: wehavemagnums
text: This arc almost makes you want to live in Hell for a little while.

name: prolefeed5
text: I love how there is nothing in the background... no craggy rocks, no burning brimstone... just nothing.

name: saint
text: A comment left by saint was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by Sakana, Connellingus, Howard, Boyd)

name: saint
text: A comment left by saint was marked lame too many times and excluded. (marked lame by straw, SSDDR, Connellingus, Howard, Aaron_Haynes, Boyd)

name: centipede_damascus
text: That is what happens when you sell your soul at the Crossroads. You end up playing Best Westerns in Hell for the rest of time eternal.

name: henrythecad
text: Robert Johnson is the shit. Rather, was the shit. Ray's a lucky man.

name: goosey
text:
If hell is full of all the cool guys and heaven is full of fundamentalists, where would you rather go?

This is kind of at odds with earlier achewood depictions of heaven, though...

name: deusoma
text: Maybe it's coming full circle and Robert Johnson sold his soul for his own wicked talent.

name: narrenschiff
text: Hell is apparently a bad vacation. I wouldn't mind visiting.

name: deovalente
text: I work for a Holiday Inn Express.

name: bixschmix
text: I'm sorry.

name: boredom_man
text: I, um, yeah. I'm specifically sorry. I didn't mean nothin' by it. Can I send you a tip?

name: heccibiggs
text: "Frederick Clarinet on Clarinet" was my MSN personal message for a while. I found it really hilarious for some reason, but it didn't really make sense to anyone else. Boo.

name: fineoakstructure
text: FREDERICK is CRAPPY!
